awd_titl_txt: Zero and Low-Field Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR)
awd_abstract_narration:
Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) is a powerful tool for applications in analytical chemistry, materials science, and the screening of compounds in search for new medications.  Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), an offshoot of NMR, capitalizes on the same scientific principles study structures inside the human body, providing a critically important tool for diagnostic and cognitive (neurological) biomedical imaging.  A major drawback of both NMR and MRI is the need for large, immobile, and costly superconducting magnets and associated infrastructure.  With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, and co-funding from the Molecular Biophysics Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, Professors Alex Pines and Dmitry Budker and their groups at the University of California - Berkeley, seek to provide new methodology that enables magnetic resonance data to be obtained without the need for the huge magnets and with simple infrastructure, thereby producing information and images with equipment that is compact, mobile and less costly by a factor of 10-100.  The research offers significant impact on technical innovation from chemistry to biomedicine, while contributing to the training of an advanced workforce.

The purpose of the high magnetic field, Bo, in traditional NMR and MRI is twofold: a) to act as a means of polarizing the nuclear spins and b) for the efficient inductive detection of the magnetization precession. Each is proportional to the magnitude of the field so the total detected signal is proportional to the square of that field.  This accounts for the advantage of high fields (and their corresponding high frequencies) for spectroscopy and imaging.  Typical magnetic fields for current commercial NMR instrumentation range from 10-25 Tesla.  In order to dispense with the high field, alternative means of polarization and detection are required.  Polarization can be accomplished by optical pumping and/or parahydrogen-induced polarization.  Both methods produce "hyperpolarization" at zero to ultralow fields (ZULF) which is in fact several orders of magnitude greater than the thermal spin polarization at high field.  For detection, a non-inductive quantum detector is required.  Previous research utilized the high sensitivity of a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) that operates at liquid helium temperature.  Professors Pines and Budker are now employing a laser atomic magnetometer that can also detect ultralow precession with high sensitivity but at room temperature.  To date, they have produced ZULF spectra with high signal/noise and with line widths of the order of 10mHz. In this project, they are expanding the methodology to include: 1) sophisticated ZULF pulse sequences for spin decoupling; 2) approaches to selective excitation of single transitions; 3) two-dimensional spectroscopy for atomic spin interactions; 4) separation of spin isotopomers; and 5) quantum correlations. The spectra and information emanating from this work may enhance the applicability of NMR spectroscopy in analytical chemistry and chemical biology.

por.por_cntn:
Zero- to ultralow-field (ZULF) nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) is a powerful tool to study molecules and their transformations in the regime where intrinsic nuclear spin-spin interactions dominate other magnetic interactions in the system. Nowadays zero-field J-spectra are measured directly at zero field by using non-inductive, for example, optically-pumped magnetometers (OPMs). Therefore, ZULF NMR allows obtaining unique spectroscopic analytical information for molecules without using costly and sophisticated equipment.

We are happy to report that all goals of the proposed project have been realized, and some results have been achieved that significantly surpassed expectations.

In particuler, our laboratories have expanded analytical capabilities of ZULF NMR beyond single frequency dimension, i.e., for the first time we demonstrated 2D zero-field spectroscopy. Novel multi-quantum filtering procedures were developed as means to reduce the number of lines in overlapping zero-field spectra. Experimental approach to realize universal quantum control, and benchmarking thereof, in zero-field NMR, was demonstrated.

In regard to analytical chemistry applications, we investigated dynamic processes and the influence of chemical exchange on ZULF NMR J-spectra. By leveraging advantages of dissolution dynamic nuclear polarization (dDNP), we enhanced signal of [2-13C]-pyruvic by more than 10,000 times enabling single-scan acquisition of its ZULF NMR spectrum. ZULF NMR technology may provide a new way of measuring NMR signals in situations where high-field detection is not possible to implement. Reaction monitoring in a metal container was performed using parahydrogen-induced polarization (PHIP) technique. Since industrial reactors are typically operated at high temperatures and pressures that are only practically attainable in metal containers, ZULF NMR is uniquely capable of non‐invasive reaction monitoring under realistic conditions, e.g., Fischer–Tropsch process (pressures of several tens of bar), or production of ammonia from N2 and H2 in the Haber‐Bosch process (several hundred bar).

New level of understanding was achieved in fundamental physics. In particular, we investigated nuclear-spin-dependent parity nonconserving contributions to the molecular Hamiltonians and designed ZULF NMR experiments that can distinguish parity conserving interactions in molecules of appropriate symmetry. We also designed experiments in zero field to discriminate chiral molecules. Experimental demonstration of the molecular parity nonconservation and ZULF-NMR-based discrimination of chiral molecules are underway.

Our results lay out strong foundation for the future research. Miniaturization of OPM-based sensors coupled with affordable and scalable hyperpolarization approaches (e.g., PHIP, SABRE) can enable benchtop (or box-like) ZULF NMR spectrometers for monitoring chemical reactions and/or for chemical analysis in microchips. Lab-on-a-chip technologies are revolutionizing biochemistry and their combination with ZULF NMR opens new avenues across industries, for instance, in organic synthesis, pharmaceutical drug screening, in situ blood tests, etc.

In addition to the direct scientific output, the project has generated significant educational opportunities, both within UC Berkeley and internationally. The latter includes our active participation in the ACalNet educational network and European ZULF NMR consortium. Our research results have been broadly disseminated to the chemistry and physics communities via journal publications (including Nature Communications, Science Advances, Angewandte Chemie etc.), groups websites, e-prints, as well as through numerous seminars, colloquia, and conference presentations.

The project has developed young scientists, e.g., Dr. Danila Barskiy, who is a teacher as well as a researcher within the Pines Lab, and his cohort of undergraduate students studying Research Practice Course (CHEM 196 and CHEM 198) as part of their degree program. Journal clubs are held throughout the academic year. Journal Clubs are classes for undergraduate students specifically focused on this research project and teach subjects of spin dynamics, chemical kinetics, and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance techniques. Several students graduated from this project and the Lab have found positions in both academia and industry. Therefore, the project has undoubtedly positively contributed to human resource development and has brought new leaders to science, engineering and technology. Taken together, it is clear that the impact of the project on society goes beyond conventional bounds of science and engineering.
